user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of create_response_object:
```c
static struct MHD_Response *
create_response_object (void)
{
#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  if (NULL != body_dyn)
    return MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (body_dyn_size,
                                                   body_dyn);
  else if (tool_params.empty)
    return MHD_create_response_empty (MHD_RF_NONE);

  return MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                                 tiny_body);

#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  if (NULL != body_dyn)
    return MHD_create_response_from_buffer (body_dyn_size,
                                            (void *) body_dyn,
                                            MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
  else if (tool_params.empty)
    return MHD_create_response_from_buffer (0,
                                            (void *) tiny_body,
                                            MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);

  return MHD_create_response_from_buffer (MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_ (tiny_body),
                                          (void *) tiny_body,
                                          MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the entire create_response_object function. There are no calls to memcmp nor any other string-comparison calls that use memcmp (no explicit memcmp usage, no macros in this fragment that expand to memcmp). The code only calls MHD_create_response_from_buffer[_static] and MHD_create_response_empty and uses identifiers like body_dyn, tiny_body and MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_, none of which are memcmp. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that need investigation for Rule 21.14 (prohibition on using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings). If macros or functions referenced here (e.g. MHD_STATICSTR_LEN_) are defined elsewhere, they would need separate review, but within this provided code fragment there is no memcmp usage to inspect.
